The CCA Middle School participated in the National No One Eats Alone Day! An initiative that works to prevent bullying before it starts by teaching students to lead the movement to change the culture of middle school. Another step towards social inclusion.

The 6th, 7th, and 8th graders were mixed in groups to eat lunch together and to engage in fun, interactive "get to know you" games together (when not at lunch). Students were assigned a number and matched it to a high school student. About 30 high school students joined the middle school students for lunch by sitting at tables with students, engaging them in conversation with one another.

Through all activities students had the opportunity to learn more about each other.

The high school students enjoyed some appreciation with ice cream donated by the Johnson County Dairymen Association.

Five CCA students and their FFA advisor were in Des Moines for the 2020 Iowa Beef Expo Livestock Judging Contest Sunday, February 9th. There were over 350 contestants from 7 states that participated.

The students judged 10 classes of cattle ranging from bred heifers, bred cows, performance bulls and prospect steers.

“The Iowa Beef Expo Judging Contest is an event for young people from all over the country to improve their decision making and communication skills. It is a time for students to be exposed to high quality Iowa cattle. The best part is it gives producers a chance to showcase their genetics while the students are improving their skills at the same time.”

The team placed 8th overall out of 30 teams from 7 different states. This is only the beginning of the Clear Creek Amana FFA Livestock judging season. The next contest will be the Black Hawk Community College Contest.

Photo: From Left to Right: Katie Anderson, Kayla Jiras, Lillie Haman, Grant Haman and Arron Fienburg

Oak Hill Elementary 4th grade teachers had a data team meeting today. These teachers scheduled time to come together and discuss student progress on standards to plan instruction based on what kids need. At this particular meeting they examined the results of standard 4NBT.5 dividing numbers up to 4 digits by 1 digit using any strategy. Teachers came with the assessments graded and worked on analyzing the strategies used by students that are not yet proficient. They then sorted students according to skill/strategy deficit to divide into smaller groups to target their small group instruction to help students become proficient for this standard. They also planned instruction for those students that are proficient and beyond on the standard so they are able to extend those learners.

Phenomenal collaboration based on what students need next in their learning.

CONGRATULATIONS to CCAMS students, Ella Chatham (7th), Ashlyn Pitcher (8th), and Lily Schloss (8th) for performing with the 2019 OPUS Honor Choir. Mr. Burkhardt and the 3 vocalists left bright and early this morning and headed to CY Stephens Auditorium on the ISU campus. They rehearsed all day long with the other 177 vocalists in the choir and finished the day with an amazing 5 song performance! Our 3 vocalists were chosen from the 765 who auditioned.

Opus is a highly selective honor choir sponsored by the Iowa Choral Director’s Association for students in grades 5-9. Students submit a recording to audition which is then screened by several judges. Only 180 students are selected for each age group (5/6, 7/8 Treble, 7/8 Bass, 9th) across the whole state of Iowa. It is a huge honor to be selected!

CCA students participated in the WAMAC Honor Choir at Marion High School yesterday. Each school selects their top students to perform in this mass choir. Due to the 2 hour delay, only these schools were able to participate:
CCA, Marion, Beckman, Williamsburg, Mount Vernon, CPU, Independance, Maquoketa, West Delaware

The guest conductor was Jesse Bunge, who is the Choral Director at Coe College. The mass choir sang 4 songs together which was chosen by the guest conductor. The schools came together to rehearse in the afternoon for an evening concert. CCA and Mount Vernon were the only schools to share an individual song from their school. For one of the mass choir songs, Sam Scheetz (a senior at CCA) was chosen from several students to sing the solo at the concert. CCA was represented well and showed the strength of the vocal department.

Clear Creek Amana Attends Quad Co. Soil Judging Contest

More than 150 FFA members from 12 schools competed in the Annual Quad County Soils Competition. The Soil Contest was held by the Soil and Water Conservation Districts from Iowa Keokuk Poweshiek and Mahaska Counties put on this event.

The Soils Evaluation Career Development Event included the evaluation of three soil pits, plus a written exam about soils in Iowa. The score card used to judge the soil pits is divided into five parts:
Surface Features, Soil Features – The Profile, Land Capability Classification and Productivity Potential, Evaluation of Management Practices, and Sustainability of Soils for Non-Agricultural Uses.

Students who perform well at this contest will advance to the district contest. The district contest is on Tuesday October 1 at Muscatine. The Clear Creek Amana FFA Team placed second in the junior division. The team was composed of Alex Cox earning 4th, Ainsley Schrock 10th, Tyler Steines 19th, Olivia Miller 29th and Gracie Downs 61st out of 150 students.

Today in the Broadcast News elective class at the Middle School, guest speaker Ron Steele Journalist and news anchor with KWWL spoke to the class and answered some questions the students had prepared in advance. Ron shared video clips of some reporting he conducted all around the world and noted some of his favorites.

The students wanted to know how technology has changed since Ron started his career in journalism and what kind of training was needed for his profession. Ron has seen many changes in not only technology but also in how stories are reported. He offered advice on unbiased reporting and reminded the students the importance of not letting your opinion influence a story.

John Wilmer was a former reporter for KWWL and is teaching the Broadcast News elective with Mark Eberly.

Thank you for visiting CCA Ron!!
